awd_titl_txt: MRSEC:  Polarization and Spin Phenomena in Nanoferroic Structures (P-SPINS)
awd_abstract_narration:
****Nontechnical abstract****

Ferroic materials are characterized by switchable magnetic or electric polarizations which make them interesting for advanced technological applications. The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln supports an interdisciplinary research project named Polarization and Spin Phenomena in Nanoferroic Structures (P-SPINS). This project is centered on studies of new ferroic materials and structures at the nanoscale aimed at developing the fundamental understanding of their properties and related phenomena important for information processing and storage, energy harvesting, and advanced electronics. P-SPINS's education and outreach programs encourage gifted young people to pursue scientific careers, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science, and improve materials literacy among the general public.  

****Technical abstract****
P-SPINS is organized into two interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs). IRG1 "Magnetoelectric Materials and Functional Interfaces" is focused on magnetoelectricity in complex functional heterostructures and its unconventional use beyond the realm of static equilibrium and linear response. This IRG synergistically explores dynamic strain-driven phase transitions in magnetoelectric bulk materials and thin films, voltage-controlled entropy changes, magnetoelectric heterostructures for ultra-low power devices with memory and logic functions, and electrical tuning of interface magnetic anisotropy and exchange bias. IRG2 "Polarization-Enabled Electronic Phenomena" exploits ferroelectric polarization as a state variable to realize new polarization-enabled electronic and transport properties of novel oxide, organic, and hybrid heterostructures. This IRG investigates ferroelectrically induced resistive switching effects, modulation of electronic confinement at the hybrid ferroelectric/semiconductor and organic interfaces, dipole ordering in molecular ferroelectric structures, and manipulation of polarization-enabled electronic properties. To address these challenges in materials research P-SPINS relies on interdisciplinary collaborations, extensive use of shared facilities, partnerships with national laboratories and international institutions and interactions with industrial companies to leverage the expected scientific innovations for potential technological advances. As an integral part of the center, P-SPINS maintains a portfolio of signature education and outreach activities designed to increase the number, quality, and diversity of individuals pursuing and succeeding at careers in materials science.

por.por_cntn:
University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) MRSEC "Polarization and Spin Phenomena in Nanoferroic Structures" was focused on studies of new ferroic structures and materials at the nanometer scale, aiming at a fundamental understanding of topics of significant technological importance. The UNL MRSEC consisted of two Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs): IRG1 - Magnetoelectric Materials and Functional Interfaces, and IRG2: Polarization-Enabled Electronic Phenomena, and a few Seed and SuperSeed Projects. Since the MRSEC renewal in 2014, the collaborative research work within the Nebraska MRSEC has significantly advanced our basic understanding of nanoferroic systems and related phenomena with implications relevant to novel technologies. Among the MRSEC significant achievements are: discovery of magnetic-field-free electrical switching of a magnetoelectric antiferromagnet, demonstration of the structural and electric control of magnetocrystalline anisotropy in complex oxides, realization of the locking and unlocking of the molecular spin crossover transition in molecular complexes, demonstration of a record high photovoltaic efficiency by defect passivation of hybrid perovskites, discovery of enhanced ferroelectricity at reduced dimensions and a defect-assisted tunneling electroresistance effect, demonstration of the optical control of ferroelectricity as the nanoscale,  and many others. 378 papers were published, fully or partially supported by MRSEC. Among them are publications in high impact journals, including Science (3), Nature Materials (2), Nature Energy (1), Nature Nanotechnology (1), Nature Photonics (1), Nature Communications (14), Advanced Materials (13), Advanced Functional Materials (8), Nano Letters (17), ACS Nano (5), and Physical Review Letters (11). 

Nanoferroic structures have potential applications in areas such as advanced electronics, computing, data storage, energy production, handheld electronic devices, sensors and medical technologies. The UNL MRSEC fostered interactions with industrial companies to leverage the expected scientific innovations for potential technological advances. In particular, the MRSEC established partnerships with the companies affiliated with the Semiconductor Research Corporation (SRC), which leveraged this MRSEC by funding from the SRC's Nanoelectronics Research Initiative (NRI) and Nanoelectronic Computing Research (nCORE) programs. Our long-lasting partnership with J. A. Woollam Co., Inc. - a company located in Lincoln, Nebraska, was efficient in providing opportunities for internships and training of graduate and undergraduate students.

The UNL MRSEC has also contributed significantly to training the next generation of materials scientists and engineers through MRSEC's portfolio of highly successful education and outreach activities. Since its renewal in 2014, Nebraska MRSEC's Faculty-Student Teams program has supported 19 Faculty-Student Teams, including 32 students from 12 colleges and universities. The Research Experiences for Teachers program has provided summer research experiences for 15 middle- and high-school teachers.  Through its Bridge Program activities, PREM partnership, and annual Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physical Sciences (WoPhyS), Nebraska MRSEC improved the participation of researchers from underrepresented groups in scientific and engineering activities. Bridge Program partner institutions included North Carolina A&T State, an HBCU, and Hispanic-serving institutions California State University, San Bernadino and the University of Puerto Rico (all campuses). Since 2014, Nebraska MRSEC has hosted 29 undergraduate researchers from these institutions through its summer research program, as well as organizing workshops and activities at the partner institutions. The WoPhyS conference attracted 655 participants, among them 92% were undergraduate students, and 95% of the undergraduate participants were female. Through science engagement initiatives like Science Slams, Science Night Live, the P-SPINS nanovlog, the Science! With Friends podcast, Funsize Physics, and the UNL SciComm conference, Nebraska MRSEC has educated people of all ages about materials science while promoting science literacy more generally.
